body:
It is mainly for avoid virtualbox on linux. And libvirt supported on macos
as client.
On 28 Aug 2015 01:47, "Ewen Cheslack-Postava" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This updated version looks good to me, but I don't have a linux box handy
> to test on and don't think I have anything to test on that would support
> nested virtualization.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/62#issuecomment-135585746.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #249](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/249/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
@guozhangwang could you help reviewing this tiny patch.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #250](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/250/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
The failed test is not related to the changes in this PR. There is already a JIRA to fix the test, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2455.

Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
LGTM. Worth pointing out that this also includes an unrelated (but useful) change to stop logging every console consumer message. Not sure if it was intended.
@ewencp Yes, intentional but I probably should have called it out a bit more clearly.

Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
Hi @fpj and @gwenshap, whenever you have some free time, it would be awesome if you could review my ZKLock recipe as well as the feature. See if it does make sense at all. Cheers! :)
The same patch has been reviewed by Joel at https://reviews.apache.org/r/36722/.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #255](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/255/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

Your patch only applies the change when using the new producer. Was this intentional?
Also you apply the file configs first and then let ProducerPerformance potentially override some configs.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #256](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/256/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@onurkaraman Thanks! This is not intentional. I just fixed it. 

I intentionally applied the configs first. This is to preserve the existing user interface of producer performance tool. If there is ever conflicts between config file and command line option, I think command line option should take precedence -- user should be able to easily modify the command line option and be confident it takes effect.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #260](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/260/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@rhauch For "Is there a way to make the sources and processors created by the topology aware of or dependent upon the supplied configuration? For example, let's say my job's configuration has a parameter that, if set one way, will result in a slight variation of the topology (e.g., an extra filtering processor between the source and my primary processor). Is that possible?"

For this case, could it be written by adding a filter with a config that depending on its value, do no-op or the real filtering logic? Since all these operations will be in-memory, the only overhead will be checking the configured flag for each record, which should be negligible.

@rhauch Thanks for being interested to contribute! We are currently shooting for a second patch next Monday / Tuesday, it changes the Processor APIs and threading models quite a bit from the original patch and hence I will also update the KIP wiki accordingly. It will be great if you can then take that patch and help adding more unit tests / java docs / reviews / anything.
Tests passed locally.

Tests in this branch passed:
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/57/console
Tests passed locally and in Jenkins once. The second time failed due to an unrelated failure that has been seen in other PRs (testMetricsLeak).

@granders Can we have that job run everything, including the `sanity_checks`? Currently the mirror maker sanity check is not passing for me (though it seems it is broken on trunk, not by this PR). I'm guessing you only run the tests directory because you're thinking of the sanity checks as useful for test developers to get quick feedback, but they are useful tests that we should always run.

Also, the tests that use new consumer are always giving me 0 for output. The logs confirm that the tool itself is indicating zeros:

```
Consumer performance 1: 2015-08-30 20:00:53:922, 2015-08-30 20:01:06:701, 0.0000, 0.0000, 0, 0.0000
```

Any idea what's going on there?

I also observed the `0 throughput`, and I tricked myself into thinking I had fixed it.

I added some counters in the loop to see what is happening in the consumption loop, and when I run ConsumerPerformance directly (after running the test with `--no-teardown` option),  I consistently see 11 - 13 `val records = consumer.poll(100)` before any calls to `poll` yield any records.

In other words, slightly more than 1000ms before `poll` yields non-zero results, and therefore the loop is timing out.

I had a 2 second timeout here so the loop wouldn't quit before poll received messages


This has been fixed upstream:

https://github.com/sgroschupf/zkclient/commits/master

I think we should just upgrade to zkclient 0.6 when it's released (it should be soon)
@Parth-Brahmbhatt, it looks like zkclient 0.6 will be out very soon (https://github.com/sgroschupf/zkclient/commits/master). We can perhaps upgrade to that so that we can write the missing tests.

`./gradlew test` passed locally (I ran it 3 times). However, there is one system test failure:

run time:   7 minutes 32.756 seconds

http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/60/console

I will investigate this tomorrow (pointers are welcome though).

@auradkar Sure. Below is the description of the problem and fix.

JmxTool should allow user to query all existing objects and attributes, such that the developer can quickly lookup the right object name and attribute name in the output. Indeed, existing API of JmxTool allows user to do this when object-name is not specified in argument.

However, existing implementation of JmxTool doesn't allow this operation. To see this, suppose you run kafka locally with JMX_PORT=9202, you get no output by doing "kafka-run-class.sh kafka.tools.JmxTool --jmx-url service:jmx:rmi:///jndi/rmi://127.0.0.1:9202/jmxrm"

This is because some JMX object, such as java.lang:type=MemoryPool, doesn't have value for all its attributes. You might have an attribute that appears in mbsc.getMBeanInfo(name).getAttributes, but its value will not appear in mbsc.getAttributes(name, mbsc.getMBeanInfo(name).getAttributes.map(_.getName)).

To fix the problem, we just need to correct the way numExpectedAttributes is calculated so that it counts the number of attributes that actually has a value. This patches does exactly this.
@sslavic I think you got the JIRA number wrong here, the PR title and commit message should be for KAFKA-2492.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #289](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/289/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
Looks good overall. Do we want to add a JIRA to move this to the java client tools at some point?

Hi @ijuma, it is passing because the `disconnect()` method is only used on a single test method so far, and there's no **yet** any assertion that relies on the `ready` collection having the correct values after the `disconnect()` has been called. Also, the `==` works because the JVM does a good job of interning the Strings, but this is not the right way of performing comparison between objects in Java. 

All in all, those are bugs lurking to happen, and I only stumbled upon by chance as MockClient. Do you think it's worth trying to devise an assertion that expose at least the collection flaw? I am fine with this approach, committing as-is today, or even dropping this PR. :)

Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

I think it would be nice to have the assertion you suggest, if it's easy to do yes.

Whatever happens, the fixes in the PR are good and should be included.
okay :+1: I am gonna include an assertion yet today. :)
